cot.content:
To solve the problem, Please think and reason step by step, then answer.
question:
who is going to host the 2018 winter olympics
        
Generation Format:
Reasoning process:
Answer:

Reasoning process: The 2018 Winter Olympics were held in Pyeongchang, South Korea. The selection of the host city for the Olympics is made several years in advance, and Pyeongchang was awarded the Games in July 2011. Therefore, to answer the question, I need to confirm that Pyeongchang is indeed the correct host for the 2018 Winter Olympics.

Answer: Pyeongchang, South Korea, hosted the 2018 Winter Olympics.

anchoring.content:
You are a cognitive scientist, to answer the following question:
who is going to host the 2018 winter olympics
I will provide you with several retrieved passages:
Passages:
['Oslo 2022 was a campaign by Oslo and the Norwegian Olympic and Paralympic Committee and Confederation of Sports for the right to host the 2022 Winter Olympics. This bid was cancelled on October 1, 2014, after the parliamentary caucus of the Conservative Party had voted to not support the bid. Already, the Progress Party, Centre Party and Socialist Left Party were opposed to the bid. Thus, it was no longer possible to get a parliamentary majority for a state guarantee. The IOC selected Beijing as the host city for the 2022 Winter Olympics from the two remaining bids at the 128th IOC Session in Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia on July 31, 2015.\n', 'Three cities applied with bids to host the 2018 Winter Olympics and Paralympics (also known as "XXIII Olympic Winter Games" and "XII Paralympic Winter Games") in October 2009. The International Olympic Committee, under the leadership of Jacques Rogge, received three bids on October 15, 2009. The cities of Annecy, France, in the French Alps, Munich, Germany (host of the 1972 Summer Olympics), and Pyeongchang, South Korea, a two-time previous bidder, competed for the hosting rights to the event. This was the lowest number of bidding cities since the 1988 Summer Olympics, coincidentally also won by South Korea. The winning bid was announced on July 6, 2011, at the 123rd IOC Session in Durban, South Africa by IOC President Jacques Rogge at 5.22\xa0pm local time\n', "Milan-Cortina d'Ampezzo was selected as host city of the 2026 Winter Olympics after beating Stockholm-Åre by 13 votes on 24 June 2019 at the 134th IOC Session in Lausanne, Switzerland. The host city was originally due to be selected on 11 September 2019, at the 134th IOC Session in Milan; however, IOC rules required that the election be moved to a different location after Italy submitted a bid for the 2026 Games that included the city.\n", "Milan-Cortina d'Ampezzo was elected to host the 2026 Winter Olympics at the 134th IOC Session in Lausanne, Switzerland. The full IOC membership will elect the host city at the 134th IOC Session in Lausanne, home of the International Olympic Committee.\n", 'On June 22, 2010 the International Olympic Committee selected Munich as one of the three Candidate Cities for 2018 Winter Olympic Games, with Annecy, France, and Pyeongchang, South Korea. If chosen, Munich will be the first city to host both the Summer and Winter Olympic Games. Pyeongchang was announced as the host after receiving 63 votes while Munich finished 2nd after receiving 25 votes and Annecy finished last after receiving 7 votes.\n', 'The host city of the 2022 Winter Olympics was elected during the 128th IOC Session. Bids for the games were due to the IOC in 2013. In 2014, the IOC decided that Almaty and Beijing (as Oslo withdrew its bid), would become candidate cities, a year before the host city was elected.\n', 'In January 2010, Gerhard Heiberg, IOC member from Norway, announced that the IOC would welcome a bid from Norway to host the Winter Olympic Games. Lillehammer, host of the 1994 Winter Olympics, and the area Stavanger-Bergen-Voss were considered contenders. Tromsø also showed interest. However, Oslo was selected without much public deliberation in October 2011 after the seven major winter sports organizations decided to back the capital. There were negative reactions from several supporters of the Tromsø 2018 bid. MP Anne Marit Bjørnflaten suggested that Tromsø 2018 was cancelled not due to timing or costs, but geography. On 9 June 2012, the annual assembly of the Norwegian Confederation of Sports voted in favor of the Oslo 2022 bid with a majority of 142-15.\n', 'Oslo–Lillehammer 2018 was a proposal for Oslo and Lillehammer, Norway, to bid to host the 2018 Winter Olympics. Along with the Trondheim and Tromsø bids, it was one of three options for the Norwegian Olympic and Paralympic Committee and Confederation of Sports (NIF), who ultimately chose to not bid for the games. Oslo announced the bid in September 2006, and the official proposal report was published in February 2007.\n', 'Milan was elected as the host city of the 134th IOC Session in 2019. The 134th IOC Session will see the election of the host of the 2026 Winter Olympics.\n', 'The host city of the 2026 Winter Olympics will be elected at the 134th IOC Session. Bids were submitted to the IOC in 2018.\n']

To answer the question about who hosted the 2018 Winter Olympics, we can extract relevant information from the provided passages. The passages contain details about the bidding process for the 2018 Winter Olympics, the cities that competed for the hosting rights, and the eventual selection of the host city.

### Extracted Content:
1. **Bidding Cities**: The passages mention three cities that applied to host the 2018 Winter Olympics: Annecy (France), Munich (Germany), and Pyeongchang (South Korea). This information is crucial as it sets the context for the competition and highlights the international nature of the Olympic bidding process.

2. **Selection Announcement**: The winning bid was announced on July 6, 2011, during the 123rd IOC Session in Durban, South Africa. This detail provides a timeline for when the decision was made, which is important for understanding the historical context of the event.

3. **Winning Bid**: Pyeongchang, South Korea, was selected as the host city after receiving 63 votes, while Munich received 25 votes and Annecy received 7 votes. This information directly answers the question regarding the host of the 2018 Winter Olympics and indicates the level of support each bid received.

### Role of Extracted Content:
- **Contextual Understanding**: The information about the bidding cities and the selection process helps to contextualize the significance of the 2018 Winter Olympics. It illustrates the competitive nature of hosting the Olympics and the various factors that influence the decision-making process of the International Olympic Committee (IOC).

- **Historical Significance**: By providing the date of the announcement and the voting results, the content allows for a better understanding of the historical significance of the event. It highlights Pyeongchang's successful bid after two previous attempts, showcasing persistence in the Olympic bidding process.

- **Geopolitical Insight**: The mention of different countries (France, Germany, and South Korea) competing for the Olympics provides insight into the global landscape of the Olympic Games and the importance of international relations in sports.

### Conclusion:
The extracted content from the passages is essential for answering the question about the host of the 2018 Winter Olympics. It not only provides the direct answer (Pyeongchang, South Korea) but also enriches the understanding of the context, significance, and competitive nature of the Olympic bidding process. This background knowledge enhances the model's ability to comprehend the broader implications of the event and its place in Olympic history.

To answer the question regarding who hosted the 2018 Winter Olympics, we can extract and analyze relevant information from the provided passages.

### Key Information Extracted:

1. **Bidding Process for 2018 Winter Olympics**:
   - Three cities submitted bids to host the 2018 Winter Olympics: Annecy (France), Munich (Germany), and Pyeongchang (South Korea).
   - The International Olympic Committee (IOC) received these bids on October 15, 2009, and the selection process was led by IOC President Jacques Rogge.

2. **Selection of Host City**:
   - Pyeongchang was announced as the host city for the 2018 Winter Olympics on July 6, 2011, during the 123rd IOC Session in Durban, South Africa.
   - Pyeongchang won the bid with 63 votes, while Munich received 25 votes and Annecy received 7 votes.

3. **Context of the Event**:
   - The 2018 Winter Olympics are also referred to as the "XXIII Olympic Winter Games" and the "XII Paralympic Winter Games."
   - The event took place in Pyeongchang, South Korea, marking a significant achievement for the city, which had previously bid unsuccessfully for the same event.

### Analysis of the Role of This Information:

- **Foundational Knowledge**: The information about the bidding process and the eventual selection of Pyeongchang as the host city provides a foundational understanding of how Olympic host cities are chosen. This includes the competitive nature of the bidding process and the voting mechanism used by the IOC.
  
- **Advanced Information**: The details regarding the number of votes and the context of the bidding (e.g., previous bids by Pyeongchang) offer deeper insights into the significance of the event and the strategic considerations involved in hosting the Olympics.

### Summary and Consolidation:

The 2018 Winter Olympics were hosted by Pyeongchang, South Korea, after a competitive bidding process that included Annecy and Munich. Pyeongchang's selection was finalized on July 6, 2011, when it received 63 votes from the IOC, highlighting its successful campaign after two previous unsuccessful bids. This event, known as the XXIII Olympic Winter Games, represents a notable achievement for South Korea in the realm of international sports.

By understanding the bidding process, the competitive landscape, and the significance of the event, we can appreciate the complexities involved in hosting the Olympics and the strategic efforts made by cities to secure this prestigious opportunity. This knowledge not only answers the question but also enhances the comprehension of the broader context of the Olympic Games.

### Knowledge Enhanced Inference Process:

To answer the question of who hosted the 2018 Winter Olympics, we begin by analyzing the relevant information regarding the bidding process, selection, and context of the event.

1. **Bidding Process for 2018 Winter Olympics**:
   - The International Olympic Committee (IOC) received bids from three cities: Annecy (France), Munich (Germany), and Pyeongchang (South Korea) on October 15, 2009. This competitive bidding process is crucial as it determines which city will host the prestigious event.

2. **Selection of Host City**:
   - Pyeongchang was selected as the host city on July 6, 2011, during the 123rd IOC Session held in Durban, South Africa. Pyeongchang won decisively with 63 votes, while Munich received 25 votes and Annecy only 7 votes. This information highlights the competitive nature of the selection process and the significant support Pyeongchang garnered from IOC members.

3. **Context of the Event**:
   - The 2018 Winter Olympics, officially known as the "XXIII Olympic Winter Games," took place in Pyeongchang, marking a significant achievement for South Korea, as it was the first time the country hosted the Winter Olympics. Pyeongchang had previously bid unsuccessfully for the same event, which adds to the significance of its eventual success.

4. **Strategic Importance**:
   - Hosting the Olympics is not just about the event itself; it involves extensive planning, infrastructure development, and international exposure. Pyeongchang's successful bid reflects its commitment to winter sports and its capability to host large-scale international events.

5. **Broader Implications**:
   - The successful hosting of the Olympics can have lasting impacts on a city and country, including increased tourism, improved infrastructure, and enhanced global recognition. Understanding these implications provides a deeper appreciation of why cities compete so fiercely for the opportunity to host the Games.

By synthesizing this information, we can confirm that Pyeongchang, South Korea, hosted the 2018 Winter Olympics, and we gain a richer understanding of the complexities and significance surrounding the event.

### Answer:
Pyeongchang, South Korea, hosted the 2018 Winter Olympics, officially known as the XXIII Olympic Winter Games, after winning the bid in July 2011 against competitors Annecy and Munich.

To address the question of who hosted the 2018 Winter Olympics, we can extract relevant information from the provided passages. Here’s a consolidated summary of the pertinent details:

1. **Bidding Process**: Three cities submitted bids to host the 2018 Winter Olympics: Annecy (France), Munich (Germany), and Pyeongchang (South Korea). This information establishes the context of competition for hosting rights.

2. **Selection of Host City**: The International Olympic Committee (IOC) announced Pyeongchang as the host city for the 2018 Winter Olympics on July 6, 2011. Pyeongchang received 63 votes, while Munich received 25 votes and Annecy received 7 votes. This detail provides a clear outcome of the bidding process.

3. **Historical Context**: Pyeongchang was a two-time previous bidder for the Winter Olympics, which adds context to its eventual selection and highlights the competitive nature of Olympic hosting.

### Analysis of Impact on Causal Reasoning and Logical Inference

1. **Understanding Causality**: The information about the bidding process and the eventual selection of Pyeongchang illustrates a clear causal relationship: the number of votes received directly influenced the decision of the IOC. This helps the model understand how outcomes are determined by preceding events (bids and votes).

2. **Logical Inference**: By knowing the number of votes each city received, the model can infer that Pyeongchang was the most favored option among the IOC members. This enhances the model's ability to make logical deductions based on quantitative data (vote counts) and qualitative factors (previous bidding attempts).

3. **Contextual Knowledge**: The historical context of Pyeongchang's previous bids provides a deeper understanding of the competitive landscape. This can improve the model's ability to analyze similar situations in the future, recognizing patterns in bidding and selection processes.

4. **Comparative Analysis**: The information allows for comparisons between the bids, which can enhance the model's reasoning capabilities when evaluating multiple options and their respective outcomes.

In summary, the extracted content provides a framework for understanding the causal relationships and logical inferences involved in the selection of the host city for the 2018 Winter Olympics. This enhances the model's reasoning abilities by providing clear examples of how decisions are made based on competitive dynamics and voting outcomes.
Please verify the above reasoning process for errors, 
then enhance this reasoning process using retrieved knowledge to enhance the causal reasoning and logical inference abilities.
Afterward, give the answer based on the enhanced reasoning process.

Generation Format:
knowledge enhanced inference process:
Answer:

### Knowledge Enhanced Inference Process:

1. **Contextual Understanding**: The question asks about the host of the 2018 Winter Olympics, which requires knowledge of the event's history and selection process. The relevant cities that bid for the event were Annecy (France), Munich (Germany), and Pyeongchang (South Korea).

2. **Bidding Process**: The International Olympic Committee (IOC) received bids from these three cities in October 2009. This establishes the competitive context for the selection of the host city.

3. **Selection Announcement**: On July 6, 2011, the IOC announced that Pyeongchang would host the 2018 Winter Olympics. This decision was based on a voting process where Pyeongchang received 63 votes, significantly more than Munich's 25 votes and Annecy's 7 votes. This quantitative data is crucial for understanding the decision-making process.

4. **Historical Context**: Pyeongchang had previously bid for the Winter Olympics twice before, which indicates persistence and a strong desire to host the games. This historical context can suggest that the city had developed a robust proposal over time, making it a more favorable candidate.

5. **Causal Relationships**: The number of votes received by each city directly influenced the IOC's decision. This causal relationship illustrates how competitive dynamics and the preferences of IOC members led to the selection of Pyeongchang.

6. **Logical Inference**: Given the voting results, it can be logically inferred that Pyeongchang was the preferred choice among the IOC members. The model can deduce that a higher number of votes correlates with a stronger bid and greater support from the committee.

7. **Comparative Analysis**: By comparing the bids, the model can understand the relative strengths and weaknesses of each city's proposal. This comparative analysis enhances the model's ability to evaluate similar situations in the future.

### Answer:
Pyeongchang, South Korea, hosted the 2018 Winter Olympics. The selection was made by the International Olympic Committee on July 6, 2011, after Pyeongchang received 63 votes, significantly more than Munich's 25 votes and Annecy's 7 votes. This outcome reflects Pyeongchang's strong bid and historical persistence in seeking to host the Games.

cognition.content:
Fact-checking refers to the process of confirming the accuracy of a statement or claim through various sources or methods. 
This process aims to ensure that statements or claims are based on reliable and verifiable information while eliminating inaccurate or misleading content. 
Fact-checking may involve the examination of data, literature, expert opinions, or other trustworthy sources.
In the context of artificial intelligence, model illusion refers to the overconfidence response of the AI. 
When a model exhibits an 'illusion' (a tendency to output deceptive data), it indicates that the training data used by the model does not necessarily support the rationality of its outputs.
You are a scientist researching fact-checking and addressing model illusions in artificial intelligence. 
To answer the following question:
who is going to host the 2018 winter olympics
I will provide you with several retrieved passages:
Passages:
['Oslo 2022 was a campaign by Oslo and the Norwegian Olympic and Paralympic Committee and Confederation of Sports for the right to host the 2022 Winter Olympics. This bid was cancelled on October 1, 2014, after the parliamentary caucus of the Conservative Party had voted to not support the bid. Already, the Progress Party, Centre Party and Socialist Left Party were opposed to the bid. Thus, it was no longer possible to get a parliamentary majority for a state guarantee. The IOC selected Beijing as the host city for the 2022 Winter Olympics from the two remaining bids at the 128th IOC Session in Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia on July 31, 2015.\n', 'Three cities applied with bids to host the 2018 Winter Olympics and Paralympics (also known as "XXIII Olympic Winter Games" and "XII Paralympic Winter Games") in October 2009. The International Olympic Committee, under the leadership of Jacques Rogge, received three bids on October 15, 2009. The cities of Annecy, France, in the French Alps, Munich, Germany (host of the 1972 Summer Olympics), and Pyeongchang, South Korea, a two-time previous bidder, competed for the hosting rights to the event. This was the lowest number of bidding cities since the 1988 Summer Olympics, coincidentally also won by South Korea. The winning bid was announced on July 6, 2011, at the 123rd IOC Session in Durban, South Africa by IOC President Jacques Rogge at 5.22\xa0pm local time\n', "Milan-Cortina d'Ampezzo was selected as host city of the 2026 Winter Olympics after beating Stockholm-Åre by 13 votes on 24 June 2019 at the 134th IOC Session in Lausanne, Switzerland. The host city was originally due to be selected on 11 September 2019, at the 134th IOC Session in Milan; however, IOC rules required that the election be moved to a different location after Italy submitted a bid for the 2026 Games that included the city.\n", "Milan-Cortina d'Ampezzo was elected to host the 2026 Winter Olympics at the 134th IOC Session in Lausanne, Switzerland. The full IOC membership will elect the host city at the 134th IOC Session in Lausanne, home of the International Olympic Committee.\n", 'On June 22, 2010 the International Olympic Committee selected Munich as one of the three Candidate Cities for 2018 Winter Olympic Games, with Annecy, France, and Pyeongchang, South Korea. If chosen, Munich will be the first city to host both the Summer and Winter Olympic Games. Pyeongchang was announced as the host after receiving 63 votes while Munich finished 2nd after receiving 25 votes and Annecy finished last after receiving 7 votes.\n', 'The host city of the 2022 Winter Olympics was elected during the 128th IOC Session. Bids for the games were due to the IOC in 2013. In 2014, the IOC decided that Almaty and Beijing (as Oslo withdrew its bid), would become candidate cities, a year before the host city was elected.\n', 'In January 2010, Gerhard Heiberg, IOC member from Norway, announced that the IOC would welcome a bid from Norway to host the Winter Olympic Games. Lillehammer, host of the 1994 Winter Olympics, and the area Stavanger-Bergen-Voss were considered contenders. Tromsø also showed interest. However, Oslo was selected without much public deliberation in October 2011 after the seven major winter sports organizations decided to back the capital. There were negative reactions from several supporters of the Tromsø 2018 bid. MP Anne Marit Bjørnflaten suggested that Tromsø 2018 was cancelled not due to timing or costs, but geography. On 9 June 2012, the annual assembly of the Norwegian Confederation of Sports voted in favor of the Oslo 2022 bid with a majority of 142-15.\n', 'Oslo–Lillehammer 2018 was a proposal for Oslo and Lillehammer, Norway, to bid to host the 2018 Winter Olympics. Along with the Trondheim and Tromsø bids, it was one of three options for the Norwegian Olympic and Paralympic Committee and Confederation of Sports (NIF), who ultimately chose to not bid for the games. Oslo announced the bid in September 2006, and the official proposal report was published in February 2007.\n', 'Milan was elected as the host city of the 134th IOC Session in 2019. The 134th IOC Session will see the election of the host of the 2026 Winter Olympics.\n', 'The host city of the 2026 Winter Olympics will be elected at the 134th IOC Session. Bids were submitted to the IOC in 2018.\n']

Task Description:
Please extract content from these passages that may be contradictory to the model's existing knowledge. 
Identify information that, when added, could update the model's knowledge and prevent factual errors, alleviating model illusions. 
Note that these passages are retrieved from the most authoritative knowledge repositories, so they are assumed to be correct.

To answer the question about who hosted the 2018 Winter Olympics, we can extract relevant information from the provided passages. The key passage that directly addresses the hosting of the 2018 Winter Olympics is:

- "Three cities applied with bids to host the 2018 Winter Olympics and Paralympics (also known as 'XXIII Olympic Winter Games' and 'XII Paralympic Winter Games') in October 2009. The International Olympic Committee, under the leadership of Jacques Rogge, received three bids on October 15, 2009. The cities of Annecy, France, in the French Alps, Munich, Germany (host of the 1972 Summer Olympics), and Pyeongchang, South Korea, a two-time previous bidder, competed for the hosting rights to the event. The winning bid was announced on July 6, 2011, at the 123rd IOC Session in Durban, South Africa by IOC President Jacques Rogge at 5.22 pm local time."

Additionally, another passage provides the outcome of the bidding process:

- "On June 22, 2010 the International Olympic Committee selected Munich as one of the three Candidate Cities for 2018 Winter Olympic Games, with Annecy, France, and Pyeongchang, South Korea. If chosen, Munich will be the first city to host both the Summer and Winter Olympic Games. Pyeongchang was announced as the host after receiving 63 votes while Munich finished 2nd after receiving 25 votes and Annecy finished last after receiving 7 votes."

From these passages, we can conclude that **Pyeongchang, South Korea, hosted the 2018 Winter Olympics**. 

This information is crucial for updating the model's knowledge and preventing factual errors regarding the host of the 2018 Winter Olympics. The model should incorporate this fact to alleviate any potential model illusions related to the event.

Here is an answer generated by a language model with the reasoning process.

The selection of the host city for the Olympics is made several years in advance, and Pyeongchang was awarded the Games in July 2011. Therefore, to answer the question, I need to confirm that Pyeongchang is indeed the correct host for the 2018 Winter Olympics.

Answer: Pyeongchang, South Korea, hosted the 2018 Winter Olympics.

**Knowledge Enhanced Inference Process:**

To determine who hosted the 2018 Winter Olympics, we can refer to the retrieved passages that provide authoritative information about the event. 

1. The passages indicate that three cities submitted bids to host the 2018 Winter Olympics: Annecy (France), Munich (Germany), and Pyeongchang (South Korea). The International Olympic Committee (IOC) received these bids on October 15, 2009, and the winning bid was announced on July 6, 2011, during the 123rd IOC Session in Durban, South Africa.

2. The relevant passage states: "Pyeongchang was announced as the host after receiving 63 votes while Munich finished 2nd after receiving 25 votes and Annecy finished last after receiving 7 votes." This confirms that Pyeongchang was selected as the host city for the 2018 Winter Olympics.

3. It is also noted that the selection process for host cities occurs several years in advance, which reinforces the certainty of Pyeongchang being the host.

By synthesizing this information, we can confidently conclude that Pyeongchang, South Korea, was the host of the 2018 Winter Olympics. This conclusion is supported by multiple authoritative sources, ensuring that the model's knowledge is accurate and up-to-date.

**Answer:**
Pyeongchang, South Korea, hosted the 2018 Winter Olympics.

question_info.question: who is going to host the 2018 winter olympics
passages:
Oslo 2022 was a campaign by Oslo and the Norwegian Olympic and Paralympic Committee and Confederation of Sports for the right to host the 2022 Winter Olympics. This bid was cancelled on October 1, 2014, after the parliamentary caucus of the Conservative Party had voted to not support the bid. Already, the Progress Party, Centre Party and Socialist Left Party were opposed to the bid. Thus, it was no longer possible to get a parliamentary majority for a state guarantee. The IOC selected Beijing as the host city for the 2022 Winter Olympics from the two remaining bids at the 128th IOC Session in Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia on July 31, 2015.
Three cities applied with bids to host the 2018 Winter Olympics and Paralympics (also known as "XXIII Olympic Winter Games" and "XII Paralympic Winter Games") in October 2009. The International Olympic Committee, under the leadership of Jacques Rogge, received three bids on October 15, 2009. The cities of Annecy, France, in the French Alps, Munich, Germany (host of the 1972 Summer Olympics), and Pyeongchang, South Korea, a two-time previous bidder, competed for the hosting rights to the event. This was the lowest number of bidding cities since the 1988 Summer Olympics, coincidentally also won by South Korea. The winning bid was announced on July 6, 2011, at the 123rd IOC Session in Durban, South Africa by IOC President Jacques Rogge at 5.22 pm local time
Milan-Cortina d'Ampezzo was selected as host city of the 2026 Winter Olympics after beating Stockholm-Åre by 13 votes on 24 June 2019 at the 134th IOC Session in Lausanne, Switzerland. The host city was originally due to be selected on 11 September 2019, at the 134th IOC Session in Milan; however, IOC rules required that the election be moved to a different location after Italy submitted a bid for the 2026 Games that included the city.
Milan-Cortina d'Ampezzo was elected to host the 2026 Winter Olympics at the 134th IOC Session in Lausanne, Switzerland. The full IOC membership will elect the host city at the 134th IOC Session in Lausanne, home of the International Olympic Committee.
On June 22, 2010 the International Olympic Committee selected Munich as one of the three Candidate Cities for 2018 Winter Olympic Games, with Annecy, France, and Pyeongchang, South Korea. If chosen, Munich will be the first city to host both the Summer and Winter Olympic Games. Pyeongchang was announced as the host after receiving 63 votes while Munich finished 2nd after receiving 25 votes and Annecy finished last after receiving 7 votes.
The host city of the 2022 Winter Olympics was elected during the 128th IOC Session. Bids for the games were due to the IOC in 2013. In 2014, the IOC decided that Almaty and Beijing (as Oslo withdrew its bid), would become candidate cities, a year before the host city was elected.
In January 2010, Gerhard Heiberg, IOC member from Norway, announced that the IOC would welcome a bid from Norway to host the Winter Olympic Games. Lillehammer, host of the 1994 Winter Olympics, and the area Stavanger-Bergen-Voss were considered contenders. Tromsø also showed interest. However, Oslo was selected without much public deliberation in October 2011 after the seven major winter sports organizations decided to back the capital. There were negative reactions from several supporters of the Tromsø 2018 bid. MP Anne Marit Bjørnflaten suggested that Tromsø 2018 was cancelled not due to timing or costs, but geography. On 9 June 2012, the annual assembly of the Norwegian Confederation of Sports voted in favor of the Oslo 2022 bid with a majority of 142-15.
Oslo–Lillehammer 2018 was a proposal for Oslo and Lillehammer, Norway, to bid to host the 2018 Winter Olympics. Along with the Trondheim and Tromsø bids, it was one of three options for the Norwegian Olympic and Paralympic Committee and Confederation of Sports (NIF), who ultimately chose to not bid for the games. Oslo announced the bid in September 2006, and the official proposal report was published in February 2007.
Milan was elected as the host city of the 134th IOC Session in 2019. The 134th IOC Session will see the election of the host of the 2026 Winter Olympics.
The host city of the 2026 Winter Olympics will be elected at the 134th IOC Session. Bids were submitted to the IOC in 2018.
